values.description:
It was reported that setting a body-fixed friction direction is not working (issue #2068). This was confusing to me, since we have an extensive test of friction direction parameters in `physics_friction.cc`:

![friction direction test](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2692916182-friction_dir_test_small.gif)

It turns out that friction direction parameters are indeed broken in certain cases, and it is related to the `Collision::GetWorldPose` function that is called in [ODEPhysics::Collide](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/gazebo7/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEPhysics.cc#ODEPhysics.cc-1124). Many thanks to  @aerydna for pointing this out and my apologies for not understanding it sooner.

I believe the problem is that `Collision::GetWorldPose` is only working properly for the collisions that are attached to canonical links in a model, which is the case with the boxes in the test shown above. To show the test failure, I added a non-canonical link to the `collision_pose_offset` test world and a failing expectation to `INTEGRATION_physics_collision`. I also added a pair of spheres to the `friction_dir_test` world with asymmetric friction and a body-fixed friction direction. The spheres have no friction in the initial direction that they are sliding and will slide straight ahead, but by applying an angular velocity about the vertical axis, the friction directions should change the the spheres should start rolling. I will attach additional animations showing the failure case and the fixed case.

The fix is in 57c8d6f, which is to mark collisions of all links as dirty when parent link gets updated, instead of just for canonical links.

While nosing around in Entity.cc, I also saw that poses were not published for canonical links, which seemed weird to me, so I fixed the logic in 14473f4.
values.title: Fix Collision::GetWorldPose for non-canonical links (and friction directions, #2068)

summary.raw:
It was reported that setting a body-fixed friction direction is not working (issue #2068). This was confusing to me, since we have an extensive test of friction direction parameters in `physics_friction.cc`:

![friction direction test](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/2692916182-friction_dir_test_small.gif)

It turns out that friction direction parameters are indeed broken in certain cases, and it is related to the `Collision::GetWorldPose` function that is called in [ODEPhysics::Collide](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/gazebo7/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEPhysics.cc#ODEPhysics.cc-1124). Many thanks to  @aerydna for pointing this out and my apologies for not understanding it sooner.

I believe the problem is that `Collision::GetWorldPose` is only working properly for the collisions that are attached to canonical links in a model, which is the case with the boxes in the test shown above. To show the test failure, I added a non-canonical link to the `collision_pose_offset` test world and a failing expectation to `INTEGRATION_physics_collision`. I also added a pair of spheres to the `friction_dir_test` world with asymmetric friction and a body-fixed friction direction. The spheres have no friction in the initial direction that they are sliding and will slide straight ahead, but by applying an angular velocity about the vertical axis, the friction directions should change the the spheres should start rolling. I will attach additional animations showing the failure case and the fixed case.

The fix is in 57c8d6f, which is to mark collisions of all links as dirty when parent link gets updated, instead of just for canonical links.

While nosing around in Entity.cc, I also saw that poses were not published for canonical links, which seemed weird to me, so I fixed the logic in 14473f4.
summary.html:
It was reported that setting a body-fixed friction direction is not working (issue #2068). This was confusing to me, since we have an extensive test of friction direction parameters in physics_friction.cc:

It turns out that friction direction parameters are indeed broken in certain cases, and it is related to the Collision::GetWorldPose function that is called in ODEPhysics::Collide. Many thanks to @aerydna for pointing this out and my apologies for not understanding it sooner.

I believe the problem is that Collision::GetWorldPose is only working properly for the collisions that are attached to canonical links in a model, which is the case with the boxes in the test shown above. To show the test failure, I added a non-canonical link to the collision_pose_offset test world and a failing expectation to INTEGRATION_physics_collision. I also added a pair of spheres to the friction_dir_test world with asymmetric friction and a body-fixed friction direction. The spheres have no friction in the initial direction that they are sliding and will slide straight ahead, but by applying an angular velocity about the vertical axis, the friction directions should change the the spheres should start rolling. I will attach additional animations showing the failure case and the fixed case.

The fix is in 57c8d6f, which is to mark collisions of all links as dirty when parent link gets updated, instead of just for canonical links.

While nosing around in Entity.cc, I also saw that poses were not published for canonical links, which seemed weird to me, so I fixed the logic in 14473f4.

values.description:
When URI to a mesh cannot be found, Bullet crashes because some objects are NULL.
This PR fixes it by adding ``nullptr`` checks and just skipping mesh shapes which could not be loaded from file.
values.title: Fix for bullet crashing when mesh shape files cannot be found.

summary.raw:
When URI to a mesh cannot be found, Bullet crashes because some objects are NULL.
This PR fixes it by adding ``nullptr`` checks and just skipping mesh shapes which could not be loaded from file.
summary.html: When URI to a mesh cannot be found, Bullet crashes because some objects are NULL. This PR fixes it by adding nullptr checks and just skipping mesh shapes which could not be loaded from file.

values.description:
Could we add this method to allow getting the current world SDF? This can be used alternatively to ``World::Save`` if something should be adjusted in the SDF before saving.

I need it to change the URIs to resources if I want to save the world in a directory along with its resources.
values.title: Added method World::GetSDF()

summary.raw:
Could we add this method to allow getting the current world SDF? This can be used alternatively to ``World::Save`` if something should be adjusted in the SDF before saving.

I need it to change the URIs to resources if I want to save the world in a directory along with its resources.
summary.html:
Could we add this method to allow getting the current world SDF? This can be used alternatively to World::Save if something should be adjusted in the SDF before saving.

values.description:
The ABI checker did not detect the failure but it was easy to trigger in the `gazebo_ros_pkgs` just running an empty world. Bisecting the changes leaded me to commit 093374a .

I'm pretty sure that one of the problem was to add the overloaded method `AddPlugin`. This could break the ABI if the method was not overloaded before. However just renaming it was not enough in my testing to solve the problem and I found needed to remove also the `AddPlugins` method to solve totally the breakage.
values.title: Fix ABI breakage in gazebo 8.1.0 release (issue #2279)

summary.raw:
The ABI checker did not detect the failure but it was easy to trigger in the `gazebo_ros_pkgs` just running an empty world. Bisecting the changes leaded me to commit 093374a .

I'm pretty sure that one of the problem was to add the overloaded method `AddPlugin`. This could break the ABI if the method was not overloaded before. However just renaming it was not enough in my testing to solve the problem and I found needed to remove also the `AddPlugins` method to solve totally the breakage.
summary.html:
The ABI checker did not detect the failure but it was easy to trigger in the gazebo_ros_pkgs just running an empty world. Bisecting the changes leaded me to commit 093374a .

I'm pretty sure that one of the problem was to add the overloaded method AddPlugin. This could break the ABI if the method was not overloaded before. However just renaming it was not enough in my testing to solve the problem and I found needed to remove also the AddPlugins method to solve totally the breakage.

values.description:
The bounding boxes with bullet and dart are wrong when there is ``physics::Collision`` elements which have a relative transform within the link. In both engines, the relative transform *is not considered* when computing the bounding box.

``Model::BoudingBox()`` will go through all links, and call their ``Link::BoundingBox``, which in turn calls ``Collision::BoundingBox()`` of all collision elements within the link, and joins them together.
When ``Link::BoundingBox()`` does this, it relies on that the relative transform is already encoded in the ``Collision`` element. However in bullet and dart this was not the case.

I added a test which fails without this fix - I've run it on jenkins on default with only the test, see for examle [this build](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/lastCompletedBuild/) (taken out of [this pr_any build](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any/562/)).

The fixes for dart and bullet are also included in this PR.

There is still some scope for discussion in this PR before we can merge, e.g. I think (as commented inline) there are two new functions which should be added to ign-math.
values.title: Fix faulty Bounding Box in Bullet and Dart when collision elements with relative transforms present

summary.raw:
The bounding boxes with bullet and dart are wrong when there is ``physics::Collision`` elements which have a relative transform within the link. In both engines, the relative transform *is not considered* when computing the bounding box.

``Model::BoudingBox()`` will go through all links, and call their ``Link::BoundingBox``, which in turn calls ``Collision::BoundingBox()`` of all collision elements within the link, and joins them together.
When ``Link::BoundingBox()`` does this, it relies on that the relative transform is already encoded in the ``Collision`` element. However in bullet and dart this was not the case.

I added a test which fails without this fix - I've run it on jenkins on default with only the test, see for examle [this build](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/lastCompletedBuild/) (taken out of [this pr_any build](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any/562/)).

The fixes for dart and bullet are also included in this PR.

There is still some scope for discussion in this PR before we can merge, e.g. I think (as commented inline) there are two new functions which should be added to ign-math.
summary.html:
The bounding boxes with bullet and dart are wrong when there is physics::Collision elements which have a relative transform within the link. In both engines, the relative transform is not considered when computing the bounding box.

Model::BoudingBox() will go through all links, and call their Link::BoundingBox, which in turn calls Collision::BoundingBox() of all collision elements within the link, and joins them together. When Link::BoundingBox() does this, it relies on that the relative transform is already encoded in the Collision element. However in bullet and dart this was not the case.

I added a test which fails without this fix - I've run it on jenkins on default with only the test, see for examle this build (taken out of this pr_any build).

The fixes for dart and bullet are also included in this PR.

There is still some scope for discussion in this PR before we can merge, e.g. I think (as commented inline) there are two new functions which should be added to ign-math.

values.description:
you can now filter by regular expression matching the entity names, and also by rate

examples:

the following filter will log all model names matching the prefix `double pendulum` and `unit_box`

* `--record_filter "double_pendulum*|unit_box*"`

this sets the recording rate to 1/0.02 = 50Hz

* `--record_period 0.02`

Other changes:

* disable link velocity recording

* reduce precision of floating point values

jenkins:

[abi](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-xenial-amd64/316/API_ABI_report/) - ok

[xenial-gpu](https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/189/) - 1 test failure which should be fixed in 2e13f3e
values.title: Add log record filter options

examples:

  • --record_filter "double_pendulum*|unit_box*"

this sets the recording rate to 1/0.02 = 50Hz

  • --record_period 0.02

Other changes:

  • disable link velocity recording

  • reduce precision of floating point values

abi - ok

xenial-gpu - 1 test failure which should be fixed in 2e13f3e

values.description:
We face the problem of having to keep the backward compatibility with gazebo 8.0.0 loading System Plugins using `-g` option. In order to preserve that functionality I've reverted the change made in 8.1.0 and add a new `gui-client-plugin` option including a warning and deprecation on the -g option.

Now if a user load a GUI plugin using `g` would get the following output:
```
jrivero@nium client-11345 $ gazebo -g /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/gazebo-8/plugins/libTimerGUIPlugin.so --verbose
Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 8.1.0
Copyright (C) 2012 Open Source Robotics Foundation.
Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org

[Wrn] [GuiIface.cc:191] g/gui-plugin is really loading a SystemPlugin. To load a GUI plugin please use --gui-client-plugin 
Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 8.1.0
Copyright (C) 2012 Open Source Robotics Foundation.
Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org

[Msg] Waiting for master.
QWidget: Must construct a QApplication before a QWidget
[Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
[Msg] Publicized address: 192.168.1.33
```
It does not prevent a crash but could help. It implement a better help system, we probably need to follow [@sloretz's suggestion](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/2279/core-dump-with-gazebo-81-in#comment-37068528).

A possible deprecation mechanism would be to leave this `-g` in place during the whole 8 series and kill the `gui-plugin` option and move the `-g` to `gui-client-plugin` in gazebo9.
values.title: Added gui-client-plugin option. Leave -g to load System Plugins (issue #2279)

summary.raw:
We face the problem of having to keep the backward compatibility with gazebo 8.0.0 loading System Plugins using `-g` option. In order to preserve that functionality I've reverted the change made in 8.1.0 and add a new `gui-client-plugin` option including a warning and deprecation on the -g option.

Now if a user load a GUI plugin using `g` would get the following output:
```
jrivero@nium client-11345 $ gazebo -g /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/gazebo-8/plugins/libTimerGUIPlugin.so --verbose
Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 8.1.0
Copyright (C) 2012 Open Source Robotics Foundation.
Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org

[Wrn] [GuiIface.cc:191] g/gui-plugin is really loading a SystemPlugin. To load a GUI plugin please use --gui-client-plugin 
Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 8.1.0
Copyright (C) 2012 Open Source Robotics Foundation.
Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org

[Msg] Waiting for master.
QWidget: Must construct a QApplication before a QWidget
[Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
[Msg] Publicized address: 192.168.1.33
```
It does not prevent a crash but could help. It implement a better help system, we probably need to follow [@sloretz's suggestion](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/2279/core-dump-with-gazebo-81-in#comment-37068528).

A possible deprecation mechanism would be to leave this `-g` in place during the whole 8 series and kill the `gui-plugin` option and move the `-g` to `gui-client-plugin` in gazebo9.
summary.html:
We face the problem of having to keep the backward compatibility with gazebo 8.0.0 loading System Plugins using -g option. In order to preserve that functionality I've reverted the change made in 8.1.0 and add a new gui-client-plugin option including a warning and deprecation on the -g option.

Now if a user load a GUI plugin using g would get the following output:

jrivero@nium client-11345 $ gazebo -g /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/gazebo-8/plugins/libTimerGUIPlugin.so --verbose
Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 8.1.0
Copyright (C) 2012 Open Source Robotics Foundation.
Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org

[Wrn] [GuiIface.cc:191] g/gui-plugin is really loading a SystemPlugin. To load a GUI plugin please use --gui-client-plugin 
Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 8.1.0
Copyright (C) 2012 Open Source Robotics Foundation.
Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org

[Msg] Waiting for master.
QWidget: Must construct a QApplication before a QWidget
[Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
[Msg] Publicized address: 192.168.1.33

It does not prevent a crash but could help. It implement a better help system, we probably need to follow @sloretz's suggestion.

A possible deprecation mechanism would be to leave this -g in place during the whole 8 series and kill the gui-plugin option and move the -g to gui-client-plugin in gazebo9.

values.description:
ODE has contact parameters `slip1` and `slip2` (corresponding to friction directions) that are described as "force-dependent slip" in the [ode handbook](http://ode.org/ode-latest-userguide.html#sec_7_3_7). We expose these parameters in sdformat's surface.sdf (see an update to the [documentation here](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/343)), but I didn't know how to use them until recently. The slip parameters are implemented as constraint-force mixing (cfm) on the friction constraints and are physically equivalent to the inverse of a viscous damping coefficient. When the slip is `0` in a given direction, the viscous damping is infinite, and sliding will only occur if the applied forces exceed the friction limit. When the slip is non-zero, however, applying forces less than the friction limit can generate some sliding. The amount of slip depends on the magnitude of the force, the slip coefficient, and the number of contact points.

To demonstrate this behavior, I made an example world with several models that have 1, 2, or 3 collision spheres on a ground plane (spheres were chosen since they have one contact point with a plane). A lateral gravity component is applied, and the models slide in proportion to the following quantity: `mass * slip / contact_count`. The models are colored so that each color corresponds to a constant value of `mass * slip`. This behavior is checked in a test case added to `INTEGRATION_physics_friction`. Note that the parameters are chosen so that 3 pairs of models (one of each color) have identical steady-state velocity.

![friction_spheres.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/42019069-friction_spheres.gif)

In order for this test to pass, I had to modify the `ODEPhysics::Collide` function to merge slip coefficients by a sum instead of `std::min` function. The `std::min` makes sense for merging friction coefficients, but slip values have an inverse relationship to damping, and two surfaces contacting with viscous damping is like having viscous dampers in series, in which case it is appropriate to add the inverses together (just like is done for [springs in series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Series_and_parallel_springs)).
values.title: ODE slip parameter example world and test

summary.raw:
ODE has contact parameters `slip1` and `slip2` (corresponding to friction directions) that are described as "force-dependent slip" in the [ode handbook](http://ode.org/ode-latest-userguide.html#sec_7_3_7). We expose these parameters in sdformat's surface.sdf (see an update to the [documentation here](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/343)), but I didn't know how to use them until recently. The slip parameters are implemented as constraint-force mixing (cfm) on the friction constraints and are physically equivalent to the inverse of a viscous damping coefficient. When the slip is `0` in a given direction, the viscous damping is infinite, and sliding will only occur if the applied forces exceed the friction limit. When the slip is non-zero, however, applying forces less than the friction limit can generate some sliding. The amount of slip depends on the magnitude of the force, the slip coefficient, and the number of contact points.

To demonstrate this behavior, I made an example world with several models that have 1, 2, or 3 collision spheres on a ground plane (spheres were chosen since they have one contact point with a plane). A lateral gravity component is applied, and the models slide in proportion to the following quantity: `mass * slip / contact_count`. The models are colored so that each color corresponds to a constant value of `mass * slip`. This behavior is checked in a test case added to `INTEGRATION_physics_friction`. Note that the parameters are chosen so that 3 pairs of models (one of each color) have identical steady-state velocity.

![friction_spheres.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/42019069-friction_spheres.gif)

In order for this test to pass, I had to modify the `ODEPhysics::Collide` function to merge slip coefficients by a sum instead of `std::min` function. The `std::min` makes sense for merging friction coefficients, but slip values have an inverse relationship to damping, and two surfaces contacting with viscous damping is like having viscous dampers in series, in which case it is appropriate to add the inverses together (just like is done for [springs in series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Series_and_parallel_springs)).
summary.html:
ODE has contact parameters slip1 and slip2 (corresponding to friction directions) that are described as "force-dependent slip" in the ode handbook. We expose these parameters in sdformat's surface.sdf (see an update to the documentation here), but I didn't know how to use them until recently. The slip parameters are implemented as constraint-force mixing (cfm) on the friction constraints and are physically equivalent to the inverse of a viscous damping coefficient. When the slip is 0 in a given direction, the viscous damping is infinite, and sliding will only occur if the applied forces exceed the friction limit. When the slip is non-zero, however, applying forces less than the friction limit can generate some sliding. The amount of slip depends on the magnitude of the force, the slip coefficient, and the number of contact points.

To demonstrate this behavior, I made an example world with several models that have 1, 2, or 3 collision spheres on a ground plane (spheres were chosen since they have one contact point with a plane). A lateral gravity component is applied, and the models slide in proportion to the following quantity: mass * slip / contact_count. The models are colored so that each color corresponds to a constant value of mass * slip. This behavior is checked in a test case added to INTEGRATION_physics_friction. Note that the parameters are chosen so that 3 pairs of models (one of each color) have identical steady-state velocity.

In order for this test to pass, I had to modify the ODEPhysics::Collide function to merge slip coefficients by a sum instead of std::min function. The std::min makes sense for merging friction coefficients, but slip values have an inverse relationship to damping, and two surfaces contacting with viscous damping is like having viscous dampers in series, in which case it is appropriate to add the inverses together (just like is done for springs in series).

summary.raw: Copy of pull request 2719 for gazebo8

values.description:
## Reproduce issue

1. Open Gazebo recording a log `gazebo --verbose -r`
2. Insert a double pendulum (to have movement)
3. Insert a model which has a scaled mesh, such as the `table_marble`
4. Close Gazebo
5. Playback the log file with `gazebo --verbose -p ~/.gazebo/log/...`
6. You'll see that the mesh is inserted with the wrong scale.

## Solution

The solution to this problem was simply to change `UnscaledSDF` to `GetSDF` when getting the inserted model.

But that looks fishy, since it looks like the intention of the code was precisely to use unscaled models.

So I went back to the [pull request](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2020/user-scaling-commands-are-properly-logged/diff#chg-gazebo/physics/WorldState.cc) where that line was changed, and it looks like the intention was to properly record scaling while logging and then properly play it back.

I manually checked that even with this fix:

* It's possible to scale shapes while recording and that is properly played back
* Undo scaling works (that uses states)
* The underlying issue of scaled meshes is fixed

So... It looks like it's safe to change that line...
values.title: Fix inserted mesh scale during log playback

summary.raw:
## Reproduce issue

1. Open Gazebo recording a log `gazebo --verbose -r`
2. Insert a double pendulum (to have movement)
3. Insert a model which has a scaled mesh, such as the `table_marble`
4. Close Gazebo
5. Playback the log file with `gazebo --verbose -p ~/.gazebo/log/...`
6. You'll see that the mesh is inserted with the wrong scale.

## Solution

The solution to this problem was simply to change `UnscaledSDF` to `GetSDF` when getting the inserted model.

But that looks fishy, since it looks like the intention of the code was precisely to use unscaled models.

So I went back to the [pull request](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2020/user-scaling-commands-are-properly-logged/diff#chg-gazebo/physics/WorldState.cc) where that line was changed, and it looks like the intention was to properly record scaling while logging and then properly play it back.

I manually checked that even with this fix:

* It's possible to scale shapes while recording and that is properly played back
* Undo scaling works (that uses states)
* The underlying issue of scaled meshes is fixed

So... It looks like it's safe to change that line...
summary.html:
Reproduce issue

  1. Open Gazebo recording a log gazebo --verbose -r
  2. Insert a double pendulum (to have movement)
  3. Insert a model which has a scaled mesh, such as the table_marble
  4. Close Gazebo
  5. Playback the log file with gazebo --verbose -p ~/.gazebo/log/...
  6. You'll see that the mesh is inserted with the wrong scale.

Solution

The solution to this problem was simply to change UnscaledSDF to GetSDF when getting the inserted model.

But that looks fishy, since it looks like the intention of the code was precisely to use unscaled models.

So I went back to the pull request where that line was changed, and it looks like the intention was to properly record scaling while logging and then properly play it back.

I manually checked that even with this fix:

  • It's possible to scale shapes while recording and that is properly played back
  • Undo scaling works (that uses states)
  • The underlying issue of scaled meshes is fixed

So... It looks like it's safe to change that line...

values.description:
The slip example used the total mass of a collection of balls as the masses of the individual balls when calculating inertia matrices. Consequently, the moments of inertia for the models were too large. The changes in 6c832a5 fix the models to use the ball masses instead.

Inertia boxes before changes
![before.jpg](data/bitbucket.org/repo/kMkRAxo/images/1829064047-before.jpg)

Inertia boxes after changes
![after.jpg](data/bitbucket.org/repo/kMkRAxo/images/3889275104-after.jpg)
values.title: fix inertia parameters in friction_spheres.world

The collision and visual meshes were not aligned for some of the boxes in the test world. The change in 087f0df adds a rotation (pose) to the visual geometry to align them.

After change
![after.jpg](data/bitbucket.org/repo/kMkRAxo/images/2331580392-after.jpg)

values.description:
Issue [#2286](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/2286/inertial-properties-for-static-models) notes that the left pane displays default link mass and inertial values for static models, which can be confusing to people because static models do not use the inertia values.

Commit 232e1f2 changes the Link::Load method to give links in static models mass and inertia values of 0.0 instead of the defaults. The intention is to make it clearer that the inertia values are not used in static models. I zeroed the inertia values instead of not displaying them because the current GUI logic zeros mass and inertia values if they are missing (ModelListWidget::FillPropertyTree) and because zeroing hides the inertia box visualizations for static models without needing additional logic/changes.

While testing the above change, I noticed that inertia boxes are actually displayed for models with invalid inertia matrices, such as static models. The boxes are just made small so that they are difficult to see. It seems cleaner to not show such inertia boxes at all, so I changed the behavior in aa2c47f.

Before changes
![before.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/kMkRAxo/images/1987339751-before.png)

After changes
![after.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/kMkRAxo/images/1801113156-after.png)
values.title: Inertia for static models

Issue [#2286](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/2286/inertial-properties-for-static-models) notes that the left pane displays default link mass and inertial values for static models, which can be confusing to people because static models do not use the inertia values.

Commit 232e1f2 changes the Link::Load method to give links in static models mass and inertia values of 0.0 instead of the defaults. The intention is to make it clearer that the inertia values are not used in static models. I zeroed the inertia values instead of not displaying them because the current GUI logic zeros mass and inertia values if they are missing (ModelListWidget::FillPropertyTree) and because zeroing hides the inertia box visualizations for static models without needing additional logic/changes.

While testing the above change, I noticed that inertia boxes are actually displayed for models with invalid inertia matrices, such as static models. The boxes are just made small so that they are difficult to see. It seems cleaner to not show such inertia boxes at all, so I changed the behavior in aa2c47f.

Before changes
![before.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/kMkRAxo/images/1987339751-before.png)

After changes
![after.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/kMkRAxo/images/1801113156-after.png)
summary.html:
Issue #2286 notes that the left pane displays default link mass and inertial values for static models, which can be confusing to people because static models do not use the inertia values.

Commit 232e1f2 changes the Link::Load method to give links in static models mass and inertia values of 0.0 instead of the defaults. The intention is to make it clearer that the inertia values are not used in static models. I zeroed the inertia values instead of not displaying them because the current GUI logic zeros mass and inertia values if they are missing (ModelListWidget::FillPropertyTree) and because zeroing hides the inertia box visualizations for static models without needing additional logic/changes.

While testing the above change, I noticed that inertia boxes are actually displayed for models with invalid inertia matrices, such as static models. The boxes are just made small so that they are difficult to see. It seems cleaner to not show such inertia boxes at all, so I changed the behavior in aa2c47f.

Before changes

After changes

values.description:
Issue [#295](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/295/read-controller-joint-values-in-joint) notes that Gazebo's joint control widget does not always show the current values for the corresponding joint controllers. Specifically, if you set control parameters for a model, select a different model, and then select the original model again, the joint control widget will display the default control parameters instead of the actual parameters.

My pull request fixes the issue by allowing the `JointControlWidget` to query the `JointController` for the current control parameters. I implemented this behavior with a new service `joint_cmd_req` using `ignition::transport`. I added a node to the private data containers for both the joint controller and joint control widget in order to support the service.

The joint control widget requests the current control parameters from the joint controller when the selected model changes and then updates the display accordingly, namely the Qt spin boxes. To facilitate this I added setter functions to the classes that keep track of the spin boxes: `JointForceControl`, `JointPIDPosControl`, and `JointPIDVelControl`. These are all managed by the joint control widget. The code that calls the service and then the setter functions is in `JointControlWidget::SetModelName` because it is called when a new model is selected.

I added three tests:

1. The joint controller unit test now checks that the (new) service `joint_cmd_req` returns the correct control parameters.

2. The joint controller integration test now checks that the control parameters can be set with the `joint_cmd` topic.

3. The (new) joint control widget integration test checks that the widget reloads the correct control parameters after switching to a different model and back.
values.title: Joint control menu read current values

summary.raw:
Issue [#295](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/295/read-controller-joint-values-in-joint) notes that Gazebo's joint control widget does not always show the current values for the corresponding joint controllers. Specifically, if you set control parameters for a model, select a different model, and then select the original model again, the joint control widget will display the default control parameters instead of the actual parameters.

My pull request fixes the issue by allowing the `JointControlWidget` to query the `JointController` for the current control parameters. I implemented this behavior with a new service `joint_cmd_req` using `ignition::transport`. I added a node to the private data containers for both the joint controller and joint control widget in order to support the service.

The joint control widget requests the current control parameters from the joint controller when the selected model changes and then updates the display accordingly, namely the Qt spin boxes. To facilitate this I added setter functions to the classes that keep track of the spin boxes: `JointForceControl`, `JointPIDPosControl`, and `JointPIDVelControl`. These are all managed by the joint control widget. The code that calls the service and then the setter functions is in `JointControlWidget::SetModelName` because it is called when a new model is selected.

I added three tests:

1. The joint controller unit test now checks that the (new) service `joint_cmd_req` returns the correct control parameters.

2. The joint controller integration test now checks that the control parameters can be set with the `joint_cmd` topic.

3. The (new) joint control widget integration test checks that the widget reloads the correct control parameters after switching to a different model and back.
summary.html:
Issue #295 notes that Gazebo's joint control widget does not always show the current values for the corresponding joint controllers. Specifically, if you set control parameters for a model, select a different model, and then select the original model again, the joint control widget will display the default control parameters instead of the actual parameters.

My pull request fixes the issue by allowing the JointControlWidget to query the JointController for the current control parameters. I implemented this behavior with a new service joint_cmd_req using ignition::transport. I added a node to the private data containers for both the joint controller and joint control widget in order to support the service.

The joint control widget requests the current control parameters from the joint controller when the selected model changes and then updates the display accordingly, namely the Qt spin boxes. To facilitate this I added setter functions to the classes that keep track of the spin boxes: JointForceControl, JointPIDPosControl, and JointPIDVelControl. These are all managed by the joint control widget. The code that calls the service and then the setter functions is in JointControlWidget::SetModelName because it is called when a new model is selected.

I added three tests:

  1. The joint controller unit test now checks that the (new) service joint_cmd_req returns the correct control parameters.

  2. The joint controller integration test now checks that the control parameters can be set with the joint_cmd topic.

  3. The (new) joint control widget integration test checks that the widget reloads the correct control parameters after switching to a different model and back.

values.description:
A first attempt to compile Gazebo with the latest sdformat (after https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/342/remove-boost-18#comment-38862155 was merged) reveled that several files were using `boost::lexical_cast` without properly including their headers, but only relying on the fact that those headers were included in sdformat public headers. 

This PR adds these includes in a first set of files (gazebo as a whole still does not compiles with the latest sdformat due to a `boost::variant` related error).
values.title: Include boost lexical_cast headers when used

summary.raw:
A first attempt to compile Gazebo with the latest sdformat (after https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/342/remove-boost-18#comment-38862155 was merged) reveled that several files were using `boost::lexical_cast` without properly including their headers, but only relying on the fact that those headers were included in sdformat public headers. 

This PR adds these includes in a first set of files (gazebo as a whole still does not compiles with the latest sdformat due to a `boost::variant` related error).
summary.html:
A first attempt to compile Gazebo with the latest sdformat (after https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/342/remove-boost-18#comment-38862155 was merged) reveled that several files were using boost::lexical_cast without properly including their headers, but only relying on the fact that those headers were included in sdformat public headers.

This PR adds these includes in a first set of files (gazebo as a whole still does not compiles with the latest sdformat due to a boost::variant related error).

values.description:
bd81e78 adds a model plugin that performs gravity compensation and an example world. The plugin creates a DART skeleton from a specified model (sdf) file and then syncs its configuration, pose, and velocity with the Gazebo model on each update. DART is used to calculate the gravity compensation joint efforts from the skeleton. These efforts are then applied to the Gazebo model.

The plugin uses DART's `SdfParser` to read the model file, which is included in the `utils-urdf` component of DART. I modified `cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake` to find this component and modified `plugins/CMakeLists.txt` to build the gravity compensation plugin and link it with DART.

This PR depends on two other pull requests:

1. A bug fix to sdformat ([PR #350](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/350)), which allows a URI to be specified within a plugin block within and an include block. (PR merged)

1. A new model ([PR #257](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/257)) to demonstrate gravity compensation in the example world. (PR merged)
values.title: Gravity Compensation Plugin

summary.raw:
bd81e78 adds a model plugin that performs gravity compensation and an example world. The plugin creates a DART skeleton from a specified model (sdf) file and then syncs its configuration, pose, and velocity with the Gazebo model on each update. DART is used to calculate the gravity compensation joint efforts from the skeleton. These efforts are then applied to the Gazebo model.

The plugin uses DART's `SdfParser` to read the model file, which is included in the `utils-urdf` component of DART. I modified `cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake` to find this component and modified `plugins/CMakeLists.txt` to build the gravity compensation plugin and link it with DART.

This PR depends on two other pull requests:

1. A bug fix to sdformat ([PR #350](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/350)), which allows a URI to be specified within a plugin block within and an include block. (PR merged)

1. A new model ([PR #257](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-requests/257)) to demonstrate gravity compensation in the example world. (PR merged)
summary.html:
bd81e78 adds a model plugin that performs gravity compensation and an example world. The plugin creates a DART skeleton from a specified model (sdf) file and then syncs its configuration, pose, and velocity with the Gazebo model on each update. DART is used to calculate the gravity compensation joint efforts from the skeleton. These efforts are then applied to the Gazebo model.

The plugin uses DART's SdfParser to read the model file, which is included in the utils-urdf component of DART. I modified cmake/SearchForStuff.cmake to find this component and modified plugins/CMakeLists.txt to build the gravity compensation plugin and link it with DART.

This PR depends on two other pull requests:

  1. A bug fix to sdformat (PR #350), which allows a URI to be specified within a plugin block within and an include block. (PR merged)

  2. A new model (PR #257) to demonstrate gravity compensation in the example world. (PR merged)

values.description: I have added a case to the MoveTool integration test that causes an exception when using Simbody. The test captures a problem in which Gazebo crashes if an object is manipulated twice while the simulation is paused if using Simbody for the physics. See issue #2309.
values.title: Simbody exception when manipulating object twice while paused

summary.raw: I have added a case to the MoveTool integration test that causes an exception when using Simbody. The test captures a problem in which Gazebo crashes if an object is manipulated twice while the simulation is paused if using Simbody for the physics. See issue #2309.
summary.html: I have added a case to the MoveTool integration test that causes an exception when using Simbody. The test captures a problem in which Gazebo crashes if an object is manipulated twice while the simulation is paused if using Simbody for the physics. See issue #2309.

values.description:

See #!/osrf/gazebo/issues/2262/symbol-visibility-issues-in-windows for more details.

values.description: Using a deque of vectors, there is no need to save the index in a member variable. This pull request also makes sure that callbacks are removed from the queue after being called in blocking mode.
values.title: Use a deque of vectors to store callbacks

summary.raw: Using a deque of vectors, there is no need to save the index in a member variable. This pull request also makes sure that callbacks are removed from the queue after being called in blocking mode.
summary.html: Using a deque of vectors, there is no need to save the index in a member variable. This pull request also makes sure that callbacks are removed from the queue after being called in blocking mode.

values.description: When sending a message to multiple subscribers sharing the same connection, the master manager was sending the same message multiple times. This pull request makes sure that the same message is sent only once per connection.
values.title: Send message to subscribers only once per connection

summary.raw: When sending a message to multiple subscribers sharing the same connection, the master manager was sending the same message multiple times. This pull request makes sure that the same message is sent only once per connection.
summary.html: When sending a message to multiple subscribers sharing the same connection, the master manager was sending the same message multiple times. This pull request makes sure that the same message is sent only once per connection.

values.description: Currently, after leaving the track_visual mode, the camera keeps its orientation determined by Ogre setAutoTracking method. With this pull request, the camera orientation is set to zero after leaving the track_visual mode to make sure that it can still be easily manipulated by the user.
values.title: Reset camera orientation after leaving track_visual mode

summary.raw: Currently, after leaving the track_visual mode, the camera keeps its orientation determined by Ogre setAutoTracking method. With this pull request, the camera orientation is set to zero after leaving the track_visual mode to make sure that it can still be easily manipulated by the user.
summary.html: Currently, after leaving the track_visual mode, the camera keeps its orientation determined by Ogre setAutoTracking method. With this pull request, the camera orientation is set to zero after leaving the track_visual mode to make sure that it can still be easily manipulated by the user.

values.description: It is necessary to stop listening to world update events when destroying a link, because the corresponding callback may be called during the link destruction.
values.title: Fix segfault when updating the wind while a link is being destroyed

summary.raw: It is necessary to stop listening to world update events when destroying a link, because the corresponding callback may be called during the link destruction.
summary.html: It is necessary to stop listening to world update events when destroying a link, because the corresponding callback may be called during the link destruction.

values.description: After an entity was deleted, visuals were not responding to calls to `Link::SetVisualPose()` in gzclient. This pull request introduces a hack to fix this issue: GLWidget creates a publisher for ~/visual to always be connected to this topic. The publisher is never used to publish any message. It is created solely to maintain an active connection with the server for this topic.
values.title: Fix issue with visuals in gzclient after an entity gets deleted

summary.raw: After an entity was deleted, visuals were not responding to calls to `Link::SetVisualPose()` in gzclient. This pull request introduces a hack to fix this issue: GLWidget creates a publisher for ~/visual to always be connected to this topic. The publisher is never used to publish any message. It is created solely to maintain an active connection with the server for this topic.
summary.html: After an entity was deleted, visuals were not responding to calls to Link::SetVisualPose() in gzclient. This pull request introduces a hack to fix this issue: GLWidget creates a publisher for ~/visual to always be connected to this topic. The publisher is never used to publish any message. It is created solely to maintain an active connection with the server for this topic.

values.description: Inactive joint controllers have default targets of `0.0`, which makes it difficult to distinguish between  inactive controllers and active ones with targets of `0.0` (issue #2307). This PR  addresses this issue by modifying the `JointControlWidget` to highlight the parameters for joint controllers that are active.
values.title: Joint control menu highlight active

summary.raw: Inactive joint controllers have default targets of `0.0`, which makes it difficult to distinguish between  inactive controllers and active ones with targets of `0.0` (issue #2307). This PR  addresses this issue by modifying the `JointControlWidget` to highlight the parameters for joint controllers that are active.
summary.html: Inactive joint controllers have default targets of 0.0, which makes it difficult to distinguish between inactive controllers and active ones with targets of 0.0 (issue #2307). This PR addresses this issue by modifying the JointControlWidget to highlight the parameters for joint controllers that are active.

values.description:
It was discovered that the gazebo_ode cmake target was not being linked to the dart cmake target when gazebo is compiled with dart available. As a result, the build system did not include the Eigen header directories, despite being required by the dart headers.

This pull request links the targets, allowing cmake to recognize the need to include the Eigen header directories.
values.title: Link gazebo_ode to the dart cmake target when compiling the optional dart library

summary.raw:
It was discovered that the gazebo_ode cmake target was not being linked to the dart cmake target when gazebo is compiled with dart available. As a result, the build system did not include the Eigen header directories, despite being required by the dart headers.

This pull request links the targets, allowing cmake to recognize the need to include the Eigen header directories.
summary.html:
It was discovered that the gazebo_ode cmake target was not being linked to the dart cmake target when gazebo is compiled with dart available. As a result, the build system did not include the Eigen header directories, despite being required by the dart headers.

This pull request links the targets, allowing cmake to recognize the need to include the Eigen header directories.

values.description:
~~It turns out that `DARTLink::AddLinkForce(~,~)` was already implemented as `DARTLink::AddForceAtRelativePosition(~,~)` which are semantically identical based on their API descriptions.~~

~~If `Link::AddLinkForce(~,~)` and `Link::AddForceAtRelativePosition(~,~)` are meant to be identical functions, then we should consider deprecating one of them. However, the `ODELink` implementations differ from each other based on the CoG location, even though this fact is not mentioned in the API documentation. I recommend that we should:~~

1. ~~Determine what the intended behavior is (i.e. whether the CoG location should be affecting `Link::AddForceAtRelativePosition(~,~)`).~~
2. ~~Write tests to verify that the expected behavior is occurring.~~
3. ~~Either deprecate one of the functions or correct the `DARTLink` implementation to reflect the intended behavior.~~

~~I can open an issue about this if people agree that there is some inconsistency here.~~

Edit: After reviewing the tests for ``AddLinkForce`` in test/integration/physics_link.cc, I realized that there *is* meant to be a semantic difference between ``Link::AddLinkForce(~,~)`` and ``Link::AddForceAtRelativePosition(~,~)``, even though their descriptions in the header seemed almost identical. I've updated their header descriptions to hopefully make their differences more explicit, and I've reimplemented their ``DARTLink`` implementations to reflect their intended meanings. This resolves issue #1477.

Edit 2: This pull request now allows DART to pass the ``GetWorldInertia`` test as well, which resolves issue #1090.

As a side note, I've added a macro which tests whether two vectors are close to each other (rather than equal), and then prints out their components, the differences between each of their components, and the magnitude of their overall difference.
values.title: Fix Issue #1477 and #1090

summary.raw:
~~It turns out that `DARTLink::AddLinkForce(~,~)` was already implemented as `DARTLink::AddForceAtRelativePosition(~,~)` which are semantically identical based on their API descriptions.~~

~~If `Link::AddLinkForce(~,~)` and `Link::AddForceAtRelativePosition(~,~)` are meant to be identical functions, then we should consider deprecating one of them. However, the `ODELink` implementations differ from each other based on the CoG location, even though this fact is not mentioned in the API documentation. I recommend that we should:~~

1. ~~Determine what the intended behavior is (i.e. whether the CoG location should be affecting `Link::AddForceAtRelativePosition(~,~)`).~~
2. ~~Write tests to verify that the expected behavior is occurring.~~
3. ~~Either deprecate one of the functions or correct the `DARTLink` implementation to reflect the intended behavior.~~

~~I can open an issue about this if people agree that there is some inconsistency here.~~

Edit: After reviewing the tests for ``AddLinkForce`` in test/integration/physics_link.cc, I realized that there *is* meant to be a semantic difference between ``Link::AddLinkForce(~,~)`` and ``Link::AddForceAtRelativePosition(~,~)``, even though their descriptions in the header seemed almost identical. I've updated their header descriptions to hopefully make their differences more explicit, and I've reimplemented their ``DARTLink`` implementations to reflect their intended meanings. This resolves issue #1477.

Edit 2: This pull request now allows DART to pass the ``GetWorldInertia`` test as well, which resolves issue #1090.

As a side note, I've added a macro which tests whether two vectors are close to each other (rather than equal), and then prints out their components, the differences between each of their components, and the magnitude of their overall difference.
summary.html:
It turns out that DARTLink::AddLinkForce(~,~) was already implemented as DARTLink::AddForceAtRelativePosition(~,~) which are semantically identical based on their API descriptions.

If Link::AddLinkForce(~,~) and Link::AddForceAtRelativePosition(~,~) are meant to be identical functions, then we should consider deprecating one of them. However, the ODELink implementations differ from each other based on the CoG location, even though this fact is not mentioned in the API documentation. I recommend that we should:

  1. Determine what the intended behavior is (i.e. whether the CoG location should be affecting Link::AddForceAtRelativePosition(~,~)).
  2. Write tests to verify that the expected behavior is occurring.
  3. Either deprecate one of the functions or correct the DARTLink implementation to reflect the intended behavior.

I can open an issue about this if people agree that there is some inconsistency here.

Edit: After reviewing the tests for AddLinkForce in test/integration/physics_link.cc, I realized that there is meant to be a semantic difference between Link::AddLinkForce(~,~) and Link::AddForceAtRelativePosition(~,~), even though their descriptions in the header seemed almost identical. I've updated their header descriptions to hopefully make their differences more explicit, and I've reimplemented their DARTLink implementations to reflect their intended meanings. This resolves issue #1477.

Edit 2: This pull request now allows DART to pass the GetWorldInertia test as well, which resolves issue #1090.

As a side note, I've added a macro which tests whether two vectors are close to each other (rather than equal), and then prints out their components, the differences between each of their components, and the magnitude of their overall difference.

values.description: Motivated by a comment by @traversaro in #2129 saying that sdformat 6 works with Visual Studio 2015, so we may as well accept either version for now until we switch to sdformat 6.
values.title: try finding both sdformat 5 and 6 until we switch to 6

summary.raw: Motivated by a comment by @traversaro in #2129 saying that sdformat 6 works with Visual Studio 2015, so we may as well accept either version for now until we switch to sdformat 6.

values.description: This PR introduces a model plugin that loads joint controller parameters from a world file (sdf). This functionality was proposed in issue #1766. The PR includes an example world file using the double pendulum model.
values.title: Plugin to initialize joint controller parameters
